questions.stem: Equine influenza is caused by a virus from which family?
questions.explanation: Equine influenza is caused by a virus from the family Orthomyxoviridae, genus Influenza virus A. Paramyxoviridae (A), Herpesviridae (C), and Retroviridae (D) are not correct.

questions.stem: Equine influenza virus has two main subtypes:
questions.explanation: Equine influenza virus has two main subtypes: H3N8 and H7N7. H1N1 (A), H5N1 and H7N9 (C), and H2N2 and H9N2 (D) are not the main equine subtypes.

questions.stem: Equine influenza is transmitted primarily through:

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory droplets from infected horses, contaminated surfaces, or equipment

options.label: D
options.text: Vertical transmission from mare to foal

questions.explanation: Equine influenza is transmitted primarily through respiratory droplets from infected horses, contaminated surfaces, or equipment. Contaminated feed (A), blood contact (C), and vertical transmission (D) are not the primary routes.

questions.stem: Which age group is MOST susceptible to equine influenza?

options.label: B
options.text: Horses 1–5 years due to naïve immunity

questions.explanation: Horses 1–5 years are most susceptible due to naïve immunity. Foals (A), geriatric horses (C), or equal susceptibility (D) are not the most susceptible group.

questions.stem: Equine influenza is more frequent in:

options.label: B
options.text: Cooler months but can occur year-round

questions.explanation: Equine influenza is more frequent in cooler months but can occur year-round. Summer only (A), spring only (C), or winter only (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Clinical signs of equine influenza include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Profuse watery diarrhea is not a typical sign of equine influenza. Dry cough and nasal discharge (A), fever and lethargy (B), and elevated respiratory rates (C) are common signs.

questions.stem: The incubation period for equine influenza is:
questions.explanation: The incubation period for equine influenza is 1–3 days. Shorter (A) or longer periods (C, D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Complications of equine influenza include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Laminitis is not a typical complication of equine influenza. Secondary bacterial pneumonia (A), bronchopneumonia (B), and chronic coughing (C) are complications.

questions.stem: The MOST sensitive diagnostic test for equine influenza is:
questions.explanation: RT-PCR on nasopharyngeal swabs is the most sensitive diagnostic test. CBC (A), serology (B), and radiography (D) are less sensitive.

questions.stem: Paired serum samples showing a fourfold rise in antibody titer indicates:
questions.explanation: Paired serum samples showing a fourfold rise in antibody titer indicate recent infection or exposure. Current active infection (A), previous vaccination only (B), or no significance (D) are not accurate interpretations.

questions.stem: Treatment of equine influenza primarily focuses on:

options.label: B
options.text: Supportive care including hydration, anti-inflammatories, and rest

questions.explanation: Treatment primarily focuses on supportive care including hydration, anti-inflammatories, and rest. Antivirals (A), antibiotics (C), and corticosteroids (D) are not the primary treatment.

questions.stem: Horses with equine influenza should rest for at least:

options.label: C
options.text: 2–3 weeks to allow respiratory epithelium to regenerate

questions.explanation: Horses should rest for at least 2–3 weeks to allow respiratory epithelium to regenerate. Shorter periods (A, B) or longer (D) are not standard recommendations.

questions.stem: Antibiotics for equine influenza are indicated:
questions.explanation: Antibiotics are indicated only for secondary bacterial infections. Prophylaxis (A), never (C), or only in foals (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: Vaccination against equine influenza:

options.label: B
options.text: Reduces disease severity and viral shedding but may not completely prevent infection

options.label: D
options.text: Is only effective in young horses

questions.explanation: Vaccination reduces disease severity and viral shedding but may not completely prevent infection. It does not provide 100% protection (A), vaccines are available (C), and effectiveness is not limited to young horses (D).

questions.stem: The recommended vaccination schedule for equine influenza includes:

options.label: B
options.text: Two initial doses 4–6 weeks apart, followed by booster doses every 6 months

options.label: C
options.text: Three doses in the first year only

questions.explanation: The recommended schedule includes two initial doses 4–6 weeks apart, followed by booster doses every 6 months, especially for horses at high risk. Single annual dose (A), three doses only (C), or only during outbreaks (D) are not standard.

questions.stem: During equine influenza outbreaks, all of the following measures should be implemented EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: Restrict movement of animals on affected premises

options.label: C
options.text: Continue normal training and competition schedules

questions.explanation: Continuing normal training and competition schedules is not appropriate during outbreaks. Isolation (A), movement restriction (B), and disinfection (D) are appropriate measures.

questions.stem: Differential diagnoses for equine influenza include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Equine infectious anemia is not a differential diagnosis for equine influenza. EHV (A), EVA (B), and Strangles (C) are differential diagnoses.

questions.stem: The disruption of respiratory epithelium in equine influenza can lead to:

options.label: B
options.text: Permanent lung damage in all cases

questions.explanation: The disruption of respiratory epithelium can lead to secondary bacterial infections. Permanent damage in all cases (B), cardiac arrhythmias (C), or liver failure (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Equine influenza virus can also infect:
questions.explanation: Equine influenza virus can also infect dogs, highlighting the need for awareness among all handlers. Cattle (A), cats (C), or birds only (D) are not accurate.

questions.stem: While vaccination may not completely prevent equine influenza infection, it:

options.label: B
options.text: Reduces disease severity and viral shedding

questions.explanation: While vaccination may not completely prevent infection, it reduces disease severity and viral shedding. It has benefit (A), does more than prevent mortality (C), and works in all ages (D).
